{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3286949,"name":"","username":"SammyPants","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sammypants/{size}/188763_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-17T17:34:58.716Z","cooked":"

So I was fiddling around with vision stuff yesterday and started running into powering problems and that’s gotten me to some extra questions.
Right now, our offseason robot is only powering two 5v items. A small strip of LEDs and an orange pi for vision processing. For our comp robot this year I think its going to be more demanding and having one voltage regulator seems silly to do. I believe we’ll have: a longer strip of LEDs, one orange pi, and probably an active usb hub (an orange pi cannot power the three camera’s I’m trying to make it use). What’s going to be the best (cheapest and easiest) way to get stable 5v power and distribute it to all the 5v devices on the robot?

I might be wrong but why not a VRM?

Voltage Regulator Module

2015 Voltage Regulator Module

Look into powered USB cables.

They have a second connection for power, data still goes to your processor.

We used these for the Jevois cameras back in the day:

JeVois Smart Machine Vision

Mini-USB Y cable, 6 feet (1.8m) long

This high-quality mini-USB cable allows you to connect your JeVois smart camera to one or two USB ports on a host computer, a powered USB hub, or a USB charger or battery bank. For optimal performance, the JeVois-A33 smart camera requires connection...

Price: USD 5.99

blerb:

I might be wrong but why not a VRM?

there’s a few reasons to not to so far as I know.

  1. the vrm can only supply (iirc) 2A and that won’t even be able to power the orange pi without cameras
  2. I believe the vrm will get very hot when supplying that much current of 5v
viggy96:

mini power module and a 12V to 5V step down converter

I have been aware of this solution and was curious what others are out there. With this solution though, what regulator would you recommend? It would need to be able to supply probably >7A for everything

Skyehawk:

powered USB cables

This, this is interesting. would save on having an entire usb hub on the robot. does still involve having a 5v power source for them all though.

Your team is old enough that you might have an old 12v to 5v converter we used in the cRIO days, it’s a grey box with metal fins and 4 wires coming out of it.

You can also modify the cable to go to another 5V source.

Skyehawk:

Powered USB hub.

we do already have one of those. It just needs a good power supply sorta like what @gcschmit has suggested. (Sidenote we’re actually currently using a voltage regulator basically exactly like what andymark is selling except we got it from amazon)

Drakxii:

in the cRIO days.

So far as I know, we don’t even have any cRIOs (or accompanying power supplies)

viggy96:

10A 50W DC-DC 12V 24V to 5V Converter

well that’s just about exactly what I’d end up needing
4A for opi
1-1.5A for cameras
that leaves another 4.5-5A for leds and that’s almost certainly enough

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-01-17T18:36:56.705Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":3,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":22.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":450673,"topic_slug":"powering-peripherals","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51921,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3100 alum (old prog lead)"},"post_url":"/t/powering-peripherals/450673/12","custom_user_title":"3100 alum (old prog lead)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3287122,"name":"acastagna","username":"acastagna","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/a88e4f/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-17T20:01:53.706Z","cooked":"

We have the DROK converter for lower current hardware Amazon.com

And the DWEI ones for higher current.

While on the subject of voltage converters , does anyone have a recommendation for a 120V to 12V converter to power a limelight ? We are looking to do some bench top testing without using a battery and power distribution hub.

I went to go look at the input voltage of some of these regulators and I’ve noticed that most of them want at minimum 10-11 volts (aka it’ll brown out pretty quickly) do you think that it will actually go a lot lower or do I want to find a different regulator?

I wrote about voltage regulators last year; there’s a fair bit of information in that post that may be useful. See also this followup as there’s an incorrect link in the first (we didn’t find it until it was too late to edit the post).

The TL;DR is that I highly recommend Pololu regulators for anything that matters. Cheap Amazon ones are typically fine for LEDs and such but we have seen issues trying to run coprocessors on them. YMMV.
